title: Additive process
summary: An additive process, in probability theory, is a cadlag, continuous in probability stochastic process with independent increments. An additive process is the generalization of a Lévy process (a Lévy process is an additive process with identically distributed increments). An example of an additive process is a Brownian motion with a time-dependent drift.[1] The additive process was introduced by Paul Lévy in 1937.[2]
